title: How to Bake with Protein Powder

methods.name: Using Protein Powder in Baked Goods

steps.headline: Decide what protein powder to use.
steps.description:
Buy protein powder online, from the grocery store, from a vitamin and supplement store, or from your local natural grocers. Since protein powders are derived from different sources, choose one based on your own health needs. Consider using:
Whey or casein protein powders, which are easy to digest and include all of the essential amino acids. Soy protein powder, which can boost bone density and reduce cholesterol. Plant-based proteins, which can be made from hemp, rice or peas are good gluten-free and vegan choices.

steps.headline: Include moisture and fat in the recipe.
steps.description: Recipes that include protein powder usually have more moisture and fat because these are absorbed by the protein powder. Don't cut back on the moisture or fat because your baked goods won't have as much flavor and they'll be tough or rubbery. Foods that add moisture include bananas, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese, cooked sweet potatoes and beets, pumpkin puree, and applesauce. Fats used in baked goods include coconut butter, nut and seed butters, butter, and lard.

steps.headline: Avoid using too much protein powder.
steps.description: Don't be tempted to substitute most or all of the flour in a recipe with protein powder or the recipe won't turn out. Ensure that the batter for your baked goods isn't more than 50% protein powder or the food will be tough and dry.

steps.headline: Use the powder in recipes for breads, muffins, and cupcakes.
steps.description: Protein powder is great for baking because it's easy to add without changing the flavor of the food, especially if you use an unflavored protein powder. Protein powder works well in quick breads, muffins, pancakes, granola bars, and cupcakes. Some recipes may specify which protein powder to use. If the recipe doesn't specify, use the protein powder that you're the most comfortable with using.

steps.headline: Make smart substitutions.
steps.description: If you'd like to use a different protein powder than the one that's recommended in your recipe, you can make a few swaps. You can substitute the same type of protein powder, but avoid substituting a completely different type of protein. Specifically, don't use a whey or casein-based protein powder in a recipe that calls for a plant-based protein powder. If you're substituting a plant-based protein powder such as pea protein powder for another plant-based protein powder such as hemp powder, you can safely make substitutions.

methods.name: Baking Whey Protein Powder Blueberry Muffins

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a muffin tin.
steps.description: Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or line it with muffin liners. Set the tin aside.

steps.headline: Mix together the egg whites, yogurt, applesauce, honey, vanilla extract and mashed banana.
steps.description: Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 egg whites into it. Add 1 peeled banana and mash it a little. Mix in 1/2 cup (142 g) of Greek yogurt, 1 cup (255 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 2 tablespoons (21 g) of honey, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract. You can discard or save the egg yolks for another recipe.

steps.headline: Stir the oat flour, almond meal, vanilla whey protein powder, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda, and orange zest.
steps.description: Get out another mixing bowl and measure 1 cup (90 g) of oat flour into it. Stir in 1/4 cup (24 g) of almond flour, 3 scoops (about 3/4 cup or 75 g) of plain or vanilla whey protein powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cinnamon, 1 1/2 teaspoons (7 g) of baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon (2 g) of orange or lemon zest.

steps.headline: Stir the wet mixture into the dry mixture.
steps.description: Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir them until they're incorporated. The muffin batter should be smooth.

steps.headline: Fill the muffin tin and spread the blueberries on top.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or spoon to fill each hole in the muffin tin 3/4 full with batter. Get out 1 cup (150 g) of blueberries (fresh or frozen) and put about 8 berries on top of each muffin. Avoid pushing the blueberries into the muffin batter or they may sink to the bottom.

steps.headline: Bake the blueberry muffins for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Put the muffin tin into the preheated oven and cook the muffins until they're golden brown and firm to the touch. If you insert a toothpick or cake tester into the center of a muffin, it should come out clean.

steps.headline: Serve or store the blueberry muffins.
steps.description: Let the muffins cool for a few minutes before you serve them. Store the cooled blueberry muffins in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a baking dish.
steps.description: Get out an 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20-cm) baking dish or a small loaf pan. Spray it with cooking spray to prevent the brownies from sticking.

steps.headline: Melt the nut or seed butter.
steps.description: Put 1/2 cup (125 g) of smooth nut or seed butter into a microwave-safe bowl or small saucepan on the stove. Microwave the nut or seed butter for 20 to 30 seconds or heat it over medium-heat on the stove. Heat the nut or seed butter for a few minutes, so it melts.

steps.headline: Put the bananas, cocoa powder, protein powder, and melted nut butter into a blender.
steps.description: Peel 3 medium, overripe bananas and put them into a blender. Add 1/4 cup (25 g) of cocoa powder, 1 to 2 scoops (1/4 to 1/2 cup or 25 to 50 g) of protein powder, and the melted nut or seed butter. Avoid using whey protein powder for this recipe, because it will make the brownies gummy. Instead, use plant-based, soy, or vegan protein powder.

steps.headline: Blend the ingredients for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Put the lid on your blender and turn it on for about 30 seconds, so the brownie ingredients are completely combined and smooth.

steps.headline: Spread the batter in the pan and bake the brownies for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Scoop the batter into the greased baking dish. Use an offset spatula to spread the batter evenly. Put the dish into the preheated oven and bake the brownies for 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Check the brownies and remove them from the oven.
steps.description: Insert a toothpick or cake tester to see if the brownies have finished cooking. The tester or toothpick should come out clean. If it doesn't, return the brownies to the oven for another 3 to 5 minutes. Remove the cooked brownies and let them cool completely in the pan.

steps.headline: Slice and serve the protein powder brownies.
steps.description: Cut the brownies into as many pieces as you like. You should be able to get around 9 standard sized brownies. Refrigerate any leftover brownies in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days. You can also freeze the brownies for 4 to 6 months.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease a muffin tin.
steps.description: Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or brush it with melted coconut oil. Set the pan aside.

steps.headline: Mix the oats, protein powder, baking powder, cinnamon, and sea salt.
steps.description: Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 cups (270 g) of rolled oats into it. Add 3 scoops (75 g) of protein powder, 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of sea salt. Stir until the dry ingredients are combined.

steps.headline: Whisk the eggs, vanilla, applesauce, Greek yogurt, coconut oil, honey, and almond milk.
steps.description: Get out another mixing bowl and crack in 2 eggs. Whisk in 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract, 1/2 cup (128 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 1/2 cup (142 g) of plain Greek yogurt, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of melted coconut oil, 1/4 cup (85 g) of honey, and 1 cup (240 ml) of unsweetened almond milk until they're combined.

steps.headline: Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir until they're just combined.

steps.headline: Spoon the batter into the tin.
steps.description: Divide the batter evenly between the 12 holes of the greased muffin tin.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the hemp seeds and optional toppings over the batter.
steps.description: Measure 2 tablespoons (20 g) of hemp seeds and scatter them evenly over the batter in the muffin tins. Decide if you'd like to top the oatmeal cups with chocolate chips, blueberries, or peanut butter. If so, sprinkle 6 tablespoons (63 g) of chocolate chips or 3/4 cup (192 g) of blueberries over the batter. For a peanut butter drizzle, melt 1 tablespoon (16 g) of peanut butter in a microwave-safe container for 10 seconds and drizzle it over the batter.

steps.headline: Bake the oatmeal cups for 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: Put the tin into the preheated oven and cook the cups until they become golden and completely cooked throughout.

steps.headline: Cool the oatmeal cups for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Remove the tin from the oven and let the oatmeal cups cool completely in the tin before you take them out. Serve the cold oatmeal cups or store them in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days. To freeze the oatmeal cups, store them in an airtight container for up to 4 months. To reheat them, remove 1 to 2 cups and heat them in the microwave for 20 to 30 seconds.

text:
Using Protein Powder in Baked Goods Decide what protein powder to use. Buy protein powder online, from the grocery store, from a vitamin and supplement store, or from your local natural grocers. Since protein powders are derived from different sources, choose one based on your own health needs. Consider using:
Whey or casein protein powders, which are easy to digest and include all of the essential amino acids. Soy protein powder, which can boost bone density and reduce cholesterol. Plant-based proteins, which can be made from hemp, rice or peas are good gluten-free and vegan choices. Include moisture and fat in the recipe. Recipes that include protein powder usually have more moisture and fat because these are absorbed by the protein powder. Don't cut back on the moisture or fat because your baked goods won't have as much flavor and they'll be tough or rubbery. Foods that add moisture include bananas, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese, cooked sweet potatoes and beets, pumpkin puree, and applesauce. Fats used in baked goods include coconut butter, nut and seed butters, butter, and lard. Avoid using too much protein powder. Don't be tempted to substitute most or all of the flour in a recipe with protein powder or the recipe won't turn out. Ensure that the batter for your baked goods isn't more than 50% protein powder or the food will be tough and dry. Use the powder in recipes for breads, muffins, and cupcakes. Protein powder is great for baking because it's easy to add without changing the flavor of the food, especially if you use an unflavored protein powder. Protein powder works well in quick breads, muffins, pancakes, granola bars, and cupcakes. Some recipes may specify which protein powder to use. If the recipe doesn't specify, use the protein powder that you're the most comfortable with using. Make smart substitutions. If you'd like to use a different protein powder than the one that's recommended in your recipe, you can make a few swaps. You can substitute the same type of protein powder, but avoid substituting a completely different type of protein. Specifically, don't use a whey or casein-based protein powder in a recipe that calls for a plant-based protein powder. If you're substituting a plant-based protein powder such as pea protein powder for another plant-based protein powder such as hemp powder, you can safely make substitutions. Baking Whey Protein Powder Blueberry Muffins Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a muffin tin. Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or line it with muffin liners. Set the tin aside. Mix together the egg whites, yogurt, applesauce, honey, vanilla extract and mashed banana. Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 egg whites into it. Add 1 peeled banana and mash it a little. Mix in 1/2 cup (142 g) of Greek yogurt, 1 cup (255 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 2 tablespoons (21 g) of honey, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract. You can discard or save the egg yolks for another recipe. Stir the oat flour, almond meal, vanilla whey protein powder, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda, and orange zest. Get out another mixing bowl and measure 1 cup (90 g) of oat flour into it. Stir in 1/4 cup (24 g) of almond flour, 3 scoops (about 3/4 cup or 75 g) of plain or vanilla whey protein powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cinnamon, 1 1/2 teaspoons (7 g) of baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon (2 g) of orange or lemon zest. Stir the wet mixture into the dry mixture. Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir them until they're incorporated. The muffin batter should be smooth. Fill the muffin tin and spread the blueberries on top. Use a cookie scoop or spoon to fill each hole in the muffin tin 3/4 full with batter. Get out 1 cup (150 g) of blueberries (fresh or frozen) and put about 8 berries on top of each muffin. Avoid pushing the blueberries into the muffin batter or they may sink to the bottom. Bake the blueberry muffins for 20 minutes. Put the muffin tin into the preheated oven and cook the muffins until they're golden brown and firm to the touch. If you insert a toothpick or cake tester into the center of a muffin, it should come out clean. Serve or store the blueberry muffins. Let the muffins cool for a few minutes before you serve them. Store the cooled blueberry muffins in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days. Making Protein-Powder Brownies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a baking dish. Get out an 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20-cm) baking dish or a small loaf pan. Spray it with cooking spray to prevent the brownies from sticking. Melt the nut or seed butter. Put 1/2 cup (125 g) of smooth nut or seed butter into a microwave-safe bowl or small saucepan on the stove. Microwave the nut or seed butter for 20 to 30 seconds or heat it over medium-heat on the stove. Heat the nut or seed butter for a few minutes, so it melts. Put the bananas, cocoa powder, protein powder, and melted nut butter into a blender. Peel 3 medium, overripe bananas and put them into a blender. Add 1/4 cup (25 g) of cocoa powder, 1 to 2 scoops (1/4 to 1/2 cup or 25 to 50 g) of protein powder, and the melted nut or seed butter. Avoid using whey protein powder for this recipe, because it will make the brownies gummy. Instead, use plant-based, soy, or vegan protein powder. Blend the ingredients for 30 seconds. Put the lid on your blender and turn it on for about 30 seconds, so the brownie ingredients are completely combined and smooth. Spread the batter in the pan and bake the brownies for 20 minutes. Scoop the batter into the greased baking dish. Use an offset spatula to spread the batter evenly. Put the dish into the preheated oven and bake the brownies for 20 minutes. Check the brownies and remove them from the oven. Insert a toothpick or cake tester to see if the brownies have finished cooking. The tester or toothpick should come out clean. If it doesn't, return the brownies to the oven for another 3 to 5 minutes. Remove the cooked brownies and let them cool completely in the pan. Slice and serve the protein powder brownies. Cut the brownies into as many pieces as you like. You should be able to get around 9 standard sized brownies. Refrigerate any leftover brownies in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days. You can also freeze the brownies for 4 to 6 months. Baking Protein Powder Oatmeal Cups Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease a muffin tin. Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or brush it with melted coconut oil. Set the pan aside. Mix the oats, protein powder, baking powder, cinnamon, and sea salt. Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 cups (270 g) of rolled oats into it. Add 3 scoops (75 g) of protein powder, 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of sea salt. Stir until the dry ingredients are combined. Whisk the eggs, vanilla, applesauce, Greek yogurt, coconut oil, honey, and almond milk. Get out another mixing bowl and crack in 2 eggs. Whisk in 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract, 1/2 cup (128 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 1/2 cup (142 g) of plain Greek yogurt, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of melted coconut oil, 1/4 cup (85 g) of honey, and 1 cup (240 ml) of unsweetened almond milk until they're combined. Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir until they're just combined. Spoon the batter into the tin. Divide the batter evenly between the 12 holes of the greased muffin tin. Sprinkle the hemp seeds and optional toppings over the batter. Measure 2 tablespoons (20 g) of hemp seeds and scatter them evenly over the batter in the muffin tins. Decide if you'd like to top the oatmeal cups with chocolate chips, blueberries, or peanut butter. If so, sprinkle 6 tablespoons (63 g) of chocolate chips or 3/4 cup (192 g) of blueberries over the batter. For a peanut butter drizzle, melt 1 tablespoon (16 g) of peanut butter in a microwave-safe container for 10 seconds and drizzle it over the batter. Bake the oatmeal cups for 15 to 20 minutes. Put the tin into the preheated oven and cook the cups until they become golden and completely cooked throughout. Cool the oatmeal cups for 20 minutes. Remove the tin from the oven and let the oatmeal cups cool completely in the tin before you take them out. Serve the cold oatmeal cups or store them in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days. To freeze the oatmeal cups, store them in an airtight container for up to 4 months. To reheat them, remove 1 to 2 cups and heat them in the microwave for 20 to 30 seconds.
sentences: Using Protein Powder in Baked Goods Decide what protein powder to use.
Buy protein powder online, from the grocery store, from a vitamin and supplement store, or from your local natural grocers.
Since protein powders are derived from different sources, choose one based on your own health needs.

Consider using:
Whey or casein protein powders, which are easy to digest and include all of the essential amino acids.
Soy protein powder, which can boost bone density and reduce cholesterol.
Plant-based proteins, which can be made from hemp, rice or peas are good gluten-free and vegan choices.
Include moisture and fat in the recipe.
Recipes that include protein powder usually have more moisture and fat because these are absorbed by the protein powder.
Don't cut back on the moisture or fat because your baked goods won't have as much flavor and they'll be tough or rubbery.
Foods that add moisture include bananas, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese, cooked sweet potatoes and beets, pumpkin puree, and applesauce.
Fats used in baked goods include coconut butter, nut and seed butters, butter, and lard.
Avoid using too much protein powder.
Don't be tempted to substitute most or all of the flour in a recipe with protein powder or the recipe won't turn out.
Ensure that the batter for your baked goods isn't more than 50% protein powder or the food will be tough and dry.
Use the powder in recipes for breads, muffins, and cupcakes.
Protein powder is great for baking because it's easy to add without changing the flavor of the food, especially if you use an unflavored protein powder.
Protein powder works well in quick breads, muffins, pancakes, granola bars, and cupcakes.
Some recipes may specify which protein powder to use.
If the recipe doesn't specify, use the protein powder that you're the most comfortable with using.
Make smart substitutions.
If you'd like to use a different protein powder than the one that's recommended in your recipe, you can make a few swaps.
You can substitute the same type of protein powder, but avoid substituting a completely different type of protein.
Specifically, don't use a whey or casein-based protein powder in a recipe that calls for a plant-based protein powder.
If you're substituting a plant-based protein powder such as pea protein powder for another plant-based protein powder such as hemp powder, you can safely make substitutions.
Baking Whey Protein Powder Blueberry Muffins Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a muffin tin.
Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or line it with muffin liners.
Set the tin aside.
Mix together the egg whites, yogurt, applesauce, honey, vanilla extract and mashed banana.
Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 egg whites into it.
Add 1 peeled banana and mash it a little.
Mix in 1/2 cup (142 g) of Greek yogurt, 1 cup (255 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 2 tablespoons (21 g) of honey, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract.
You can discard or save the egg yolks for another recipe.
Stir the oat flour, almond meal, vanilla whey protein powder, cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda, and orange zest.
Get out another mixing bowl and measure 1 cup (90 g) of oat flour into it.

Stir in 1/4 cup (24 g) of almond flour, 3 scoops (about 3/4 cup or 75 g) of plain or vanilla whey protein powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cinnamon, 1 1/2 teaspoons (7 g) of baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon (2 g) of orange or lemon zest.
Stir the wet mixture into the dry mixture.
Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir them until they're incorporated.
The muffin batter should be smooth.
Fill the muffin tin and spread the blueberries on top.
Use a cookie scoop or spoon to fill each hole in the muffin tin 3/4 full with batter.
Get out 1 cup (150 g) of blueberries (fresh or frozen) and put about 8 berries on top of each muffin.
Avoid pushing the blueberries into the muffin batter or they may sink to the bottom.
Bake the blueberry muffins for 20 minutes.
Put the muffin tin into the preheated oven and cook the muffins until they're golden brown and firm to the touch.
If you insert a toothpick or cake tester into the center of a muffin, it should come out clean.
Serve or store the blueberry muffins.
Let the muffins cool for a few minutes before you serve them.
Store the cooled blueberry muffins in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.
Making Protein-Powder Brownies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and prepare a baking dish.
Get out an 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20-cm) baking dish or a small loaf pan.
Spray it with cooking spray to prevent the brownies from sticking.
Melt the nut or seed butter.
Put 1/2 cup (125 g) of smooth nut or seed butter into a microwave-safe bowl or small saucepan on the stove.
Microwave the nut or seed butter for 20 to 30 seconds or heat it over medium-heat on the stove.
Heat the nut or seed butter for a few minutes, so it melts.
Put the bananas, cocoa powder, protein powder, and melted nut butter into a blender.
Peel 3 medium, overripe bananas and put them into a blender.
Add 1/4 cup (25 g) of cocoa powder, 1 to 2 scoops (1/4 to 1/2 cup or 25 to 50 g) of protein powder, and the melted nut or seed butter.
Avoid using whey protein powder for this recipe, because it will make the brownies gummy.
Instead, use plant-based, soy, or vegan protein powder.
Blend the ingredients for 30 seconds.
Put the lid on your blender and turn it on for about 30 seconds, so the brownie ingredients are completely combined and smooth.
Spread the batter in the pan and bake the brownies for 20 minutes.
Scoop the batter into the greased baking dish.
Use an offset spatula to spread the batter evenly.
Put the dish into the preheated oven and bake the brownies for 20 minutes.
Check the brownies and remove them from the oven.
Insert a toothpick or cake tester to see if the brownies have finished cooking.
The tester or toothpick should come out clean.
If it doesn't, return the brownies to the oven for another 3 to 5 minutes.
Remove the cooked brownies and let them cool completely in the pan.
Slice and serve the protein powder brownies.
Cut the brownies into as many pieces as you like.
You should be able to get around 9 standard sized brownies.
Refrigerate any leftover brownies in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days.
You can also freeze the brownies for 4 to 6 months.
Baking Protein Powder Oatmeal Cups Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease a muffin tin.
Spray a 12-hole muffin tin with cooking spray or brush it with melted coconut oil.
Set the pan aside.
Mix the oats, protein powder, baking powder, cinnamon, and sea salt.
Get out a large mixing bowl and place 3 cups (270 g) of rolled oats into it.
Add 3 scoops (75 g) of protein powder, 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking powder, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of sea salt.
Stir until the dry ingredients are combined.
Whisk the eggs, vanilla, applesauce, Greek yogurt, coconut oil, honey, and almond milk.
Get out another mixing bowl and crack in 2 eggs.

Whisk in 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract, 1/2 cup (128 g) of unsweetened applesauce, 1/2 cup (142 g) of plain Greek yogurt, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of melted coconut oil, 1/4 cup (85 g) of honey, and 1 cup (240 ml) of unsweetened almond milk until they're combined.
Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients.
Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients and stir until they're just combined.
Spoon the batter into the tin.
Divide the batter evenly between the 12 holes of the greased muffin tin.
Sprinkle the hemp seeds and optional toppings over the batter.
Measure 2 tablespoons (20 g) of hemp seeds and scatter them evenly over the batter in the muffin tins.
Decide if you'd like to top the oatmeal cups with chocolate chips, blueberries, or peanut butter.
If so, sprinkle 6 tablespoons (63 g) of chocolate chips or 3/4 cup (192 g) of blueberries over the batter.
For a peanut butter drizzle, melt 1 tablespoon (16 g) of peanut butter in a microwave-safe container for 10 seconds and drizzle it over the batter.
Bake the oatmeal cups for 15 to 20 minutes.
Put the tin into the preheated oven and cook the cups until they become golden and completely cooked throughout.
Cool the oatmeal cups for 20 minutes.
Remove the tin from the oven and let the oatmeal cups cool completely in the tin before you take them out.
Serve the cold oatmeal cups or store them in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days.
To freeze the oatmeal cups, store them in an airtight container for up to 4 months.
To reheat them, remove 1 to 2 cups and heat them in the microwave for 20 to 30 seconds.
tyn_section: 8 x 8-inch (20 x 20-cm) baking dish or a small loaf pan
tyn_model: plain or vanilla whey protein powder
